numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows information about admission to elite colleges.
2. I notice that legacy applicants with a wealthier background have a greater opportunity to be admitted to elite colleges.
3. I notice that non-legacy applicants with a poorer background have a lower opportunity to be admitted to elite colleges.
4. The income rank of parents can increase.
5. If the income rank of parents increases, then a legacy applicant can be up to 7 times as likely to be admitted as a non-legacy applicant.
6. A non-legacy applicant with no benefits can be a little more than 2 times as likely to be admitted.
7. All students can have the same test scores.
8. I wonder why colleges accept students with a financially stable background.
9. I think that colleges do not give an equal opportunity to all students.
10. I ask whether colleges believe that wealthier students can pay college debt more easily than poorer students.
11. This issue relates to me and my community.
12. High school students in my community prepare to make important decisions about colleges.
13. Colleges consider background and legacy status in admissions.
14. These aspects can affect the acceptance rate for applicants in my community.
15. The headline is: Step 1 is money and Step 2 is a legacy and then the college welcomes the applicant.
